The Buddha, revered by the multitude of sages, with spiritual powers and freedom to respond,
Takes on forms in accordance with the various types of beings, and his voice is also like this.
Those who see and hear attain peace and comfort, none do not have a mind of faith and reverence,
Therefore I take refuge, wishing to be universally like the World-Honored One.
The profound bodhisattva precepts, with merit and virtue inconceivable,
Those who receive them attain peace and comfort, with blessings and wisdom arising day and night.
The buddhas always think of them with protection, and the myriad practices gradually fill up,
With the six pÄramitÄs and the four immeasurable minds, universally delivering all the blind masses.
Hands and feet should not commit offenses, speech should be restrained and in accord with practice,
Always delighting in being in samÄdhi, this is called a true bhiká¹£u.
Upright and free from flattery and deceit, always together with the sages,
Loving the assembly as if nurturing oneself, this is called a true bodhisattva.
All greatly virtuous ones!
Listen single-mindedly, listen single-mindedly, and contemplate it well.
I now wish to explain the precepts of merit and virtue that the buddhas and bodhisattvas of the three times have accomplished to benefit all sentient beings.
Thus, those who abide in the bodhisattva precepts have four pÄrÄjika offenses.
What are the four?
If a bodhisattva praises oneself and disparages others for the sake of profit, this is called a bodhisattva's pÄrÄjika offense.

If a bodhisattva has abundant wealth and possessions, and poor and suffering people come to beg, if the bodhisattva is stingy and greedy, lacks a compassionate mind, and does not give even a single coin of money, and does not even explain a single verse for those seeking the Dharma, this is called a bodhisattva's pÄrÄjika offense.

If a bodhisattva, out of anger, speaks evil words to another person, abuses them, strikes them with the hand, or hits them with a stick or stone, and still does not stop, and the other person seeks to repent, speaks good words, and apologizes, but the bodhisattva still holds a grudge and does not let go of their anger, this is called a bodhisattva's pÄrÄjika offense.

If a bodhisattva slanders the bodhisattva canon themselves, or sees others slandering it and approves of their words, and if they do not believe it themselves but instead supports the words of others, or if they understand it themselves or receive it from others, this is called a bodhisattva's pÄrÄjika offense.
Thus, a bodhisattva should not violate even one of these four pÄrÄjika offenses, let alone all of them!
If there are any who violate them, they are not called bodhisattvas.
In their present body, they are unable to adorn bodhi, nor can they cause their mind to be tranquil. They are like bodhisattvas but not true bodhisattvas.
There are three types of violations:
There are soft, middling, and superior.
If the violation is in the soft or middling mind, it is not called a loss.
If one violates the superior precepts, it is called a loss.
What are the superior ones?
If one violates the superior four precepts, frequently enjoys violating them, has no sense of shame, and does not repent, this is called a superior violation.
Although a bodhisattva violates the superior four precepts, it is not a permanent loss.
It is like a bhiká¹£u who violates the four and is permanently expelled.
A bodhisattva is not like this.
Why is it so?
Because a bhiká¹£u who violates the four has no way to receive [the precepts] again.
Although a bodhisattva violates [the precepts], it is possible to receive them again. Therefore, it is not the same.
In brief, there are two things that cause the loss of the bodhisattva precepts: first, abandoning the aspiration for enlightenment; second, a superior evil mind.
Except for these two things, if one abandons this body, the precepts will never be lost.
From then on, in every life, one will always have these precepts. If one does not remember and encounters a good friend again, and receives them again, it is not called a new attainment.
In this way, the bodhisattva precepts should be known and understood, with the characteristics of offenses and non-offenses, and the distinctions of soft, medium, and superior.

In this way, those who abide in the bodhisattva precepts should make offerings to the buddhas, stupas, and images every day, and next make offerings to the Dharma, Dharma practitioners, and the Mahayana scriptures of the bodhisattva canon, make offerings to the saá¹…gha and all bodhisattvas dwelling on the earth in the ten directions.

In the day and night, make offerings to the Three Jewels according to one's ability, up to a single thought, a single prostration, a single four-line verse, and make offerings with a faithful mind, without negligence.
If one is disrespectful and falls into a state of arrogance, one commits a grave offense.
If one forgets or makes a mistake, one commits a minor offense.

Not committing an offense means if one is sick or insane, or if one has a pure mind and has attained the bodhisattva stage, like a srota-Äpanna who attains an indestructible pure mind and is always able to make offerings to the Three Jewels without interruption. This is called not committing an offense.
If a bodhisattva is insatiable, greedily attached to offerings, and does not control the mind, it is a grave offense.
Not an offense: if, although greedy for offerings, one always feels remorse,
thinking, I should diligently eliminate this thought.
If one restrains the greedy mind to the utmost, the greedy mind still arises, or if one takes a small profit to help eliminate great greed, this is called not an offense.

If a bodhisattva, seeing an elder, a venerable one, a senior with virtue equal to one's own teacher or fellow student, gives rise to a mind of arrogance and anger, does not rise to welcome, bow, or give up one's seat, even if there is conversation, does not listen to others' talk, and if asked a question does not answer truthfully, it is a grave offense.
If there is no intention of arrogance, anger, or delusion, but simply laziness or a distracted mind, it is a minor offense.ğŸ”½Here is the corrected and aligned text:

Not violating means if one is sick, if one is insane, if one is sleeping at the time, if one is listening to the Dharma or expounding the Dharma, if one is speaking with another person first, if one is subduing and eliminating evil to increase goodness, if there is a monastic rule to protect the intentions of many people, this is called not violating.

If a bodhisattva, when a donor comes to invite him, whether to his own house or to the monastery, to provide what is necessary, and the bodhisattva out of arrogance, anger, or contempt does not go to accept it, he commits a grave offense.
If he does not go out of laziness, he commits a minor offense.

Not violating means if one is sick or insane, if it is far away or the road is dangerous, if it is to subdue and eliminate evil to increase goodness, if one has missed the invitation, if it is to cultivate goodness, if it is to listen to what has not been heard, if one knows that the host of the invitation wishes to cause trouble, if there is a monastic rule to protect the intentions of many people, this is called not violating.

Bodhisattvas, if they obtain gold, silver, lapis lazuli, and various other precious things needed by others, as well as treasure buried underground without an owner, should take them all, thinking to turn around and give them away.
If, out of an evil mind of anger, they do not take them, they commit a grave offense of defilement.
If they have the thought:
'I do not give to others,'
and make excuses, or if they are lazy, they commit a minor offense of defilement.

There is no offense if they are insane, if they are taming and subduing evil to increase goodness, if they know that after receiving [the gift], they will definitely give rise to attachment, if they know that after giving, they will give rise to regret, if they know that the donor will go mad from giving, if they fear that the donor will suffer from poverty after giving, if they know that the gift belongs to the Three Jewels, if they know that the gift was obtained through robbery, if they know that after receiving it, they will obtain much suffering and distress, such as trouble with the king, robbery, death, imprisonment, bad reputation spreading, or being banished from the country, this is called not an offense.
If a bodhisattva, when others come seeking the Dharma, does not teach them out of a hateful and resentful mind, they commit a grave offense.
If they do not teach out of laziness, they commit a minor offense.

There is no offense if they are non-Buddhists seeking the Dharma, fearing they will slander it; if they are sick or insane; if it is to subdue and eliminate evil and increase goodness; if they know the person in front does not understand the meaning; if the person in front is not respectful and does not serve properly; if the person in front has dull faculties and does not understand the profound Dharma, fearing they will give rise to wrong views; if they know that after hearing it, they will break their original mind and destroy the true Dharma; if they know that after hearing it, they will definitely go to those who are not vessels and proclaim it to them. This is called not an offense.

If a bodhisattva sees evil beings who violate the precepts, destroy the prohibitions, and commit various offenses, and the bodhisattva knows they can be transformed for good, if they abandon them without teaching out of an evil or angry mind, they commit a grave offense.
Why is it so?
Bodhisattvas do not give rise to a compassionate mind towards those who purely uphold precepts in body, speech, and mind.
If they see evil people who violate precepts, destroy prohibitions, and commit various offenses, they give rise to extreme compassion, and therefore there are offenses.
There is no offense if one is insane, or if it is to subdue and eliminate evil and increase goodness, or if there is a monastic rule to protect the minds of many people. This is called no offense.

As instructed by the Buddha, the prÄtimoká¹£a and the Vinaya are to be upheld in order to make the unbelieving believe and increase the faith of those who already believe. The precepts of the Å›rÄvakas and the bodhisattvas are the same without distinction.
Why is it so?
ÅšrÄvakas follow their own self-interest, and they still learn in order to make the unbelieving believe and increase the faith of those who already believe.
How much more so for the bodhisattvas' practice and learning, which is always for the sake of sentient beings, how could they not be able to do so!
Therefore, it is called the same without offense.
As instructed by the Buddha, the Å›rÄvakas should have few desires and do few things.
The bodhisattvas are not like this.
Why is it so?
Following the pursuit of one's own benefit without benefiting others is the good of the Å›rÄvakas.
If a bodhisattva were to do so, they would not be called a bodhisattva.
For the sake of others, one may accept up to a hundred thousand robes, from non-relatives, brahmins, and householders, seeking to the utmost of their ability.
As with robes, so it is with alms bowls.

For the sake of others, and for the sake of begging for thread to instruct weavers to weave, keeping silk garments, accepting gold and silver up to a hundred thousand, such matters are different from the Å›rÄvakas.

If a bodhisattva, for the sake of sentient beings, with an angry and evil mind, does little and has few causes and conditions, abandoning sentient beings and staying alone, they commit a grave offense.
If with a lazy mind, desiring little and having few affairs, they stay there, they commit a minor offense.
There are five unwholesome things for bodhisattvas:
1. flattery, 2. flowery language, 3. hypocrisy, 4. seeking profit with profit, 5. wrong livelihood.
If one has these five things and does not restrain or stop because of shame, one commits a grave offense.
Not committing an offense means being aware that it is not the Dharma and always wanting to restrain oneself. This is called not committing an offense.
A bodhisattva, out of playfulness, distraction, or a loud voice, makes non-dignified sounds that make others laugh.
If one is despised by the assembly, one commits a grave offense.
If one does it out of a past habit or forgetfulness, one commits a minor offense.

Not committing an offense means being aware that it is not the Dharma and always wanting to restrain oneself, or if an outsider is angry and one wants to subdue them, or if one wants to release someone who is suffering, or if one wants to include them in one's playfulness, or if one wants to reconcile two people who are arguing, this is called not committing an offense.
A bodhisattva, seeing like this and speaking like this:
'A bodhisattva should not delight in nirvÄá¹‡a, should turn their back on nirvÄá¹‡a, should not fear afflictions, and should not extinguish afflictions.
Why is it so?
Because bodhisattvas go through birth and death for three asaá¹ƒkhyeya kalpas.
If one speaks like this, one commits a grave offense of contaminated wrongdoing.
Why is it so?
Because if a bodhisattva delights in nirvÄá¹‡a and fears afflictions, it is not comparable to the Å›rÄvakas even a thousand or ten thousand times.
Why is it so?
Because the Å›rÄvakas act for their own benefit, while the bodhisattvas always act for the sake of all sentient beings.
Although the bodhisattvas dwell in the contaminated, they attain mastery over extinguishing afflictions, surpassing the arhats who dwell in the uncontaminated.
If the bodhisattvas give rise to physical and verbal actions, they should protect themselves and not cause others to be lazy and sinful.
If they intentionally do not protect themselves and cause others to be lazy and sinful, they commit a grave offense of contaminated wrongdoing.
If they do not intentionally protect themselves and let their actions cause others to sin, they commit a minor offense of wrongdoing.

There is no offense if they are non-Buddhists, or if they act in accordance with the Dharma when following the renunciant life, or if they encounter many angry and evil people. This is called no offense.
If a bodhisattva sees that a sentient being in front of them needs to be struck with pain in order to benefit them, but out of self-protection does not punish them, they commit a minor offense.
Not committing an offense means if the benefit is small and the suffering is great, this is called not committing an offense.
If a bodhisattva responds to scolding with scolding, to anger with anger, to beating with beating, or to pulling with pulling, they commit a grave offense.
If a bodhisattva quarrels with others and bears grudges, with an evil mind, an angry mind, or an arrogant mind, and does not repent in accordance with the Dharma, they commit a grave offense.
If they are lazy and negligent and do not seek repentance even once, they commit a minor offense.

Not committing an offense means if it is for taming and eliminating evil and increasing goodness, if they are non-Buddhists who will definitely act contrary to the Dharma, if they enjoy quarreling and bearing grudges, if they know that person will never accept repentance, or if they repent towards them but they become even more arrogant, this is called not committing an offense.

If a bodhisattva harbors resentment towards others and, when others sincerely repent in accordance with the Dharma, the bodhisattva out of malice does not accept it and causes trouble for others, it is a grave offense.
If one does not accept others' repentance without a mind of anger, it is a minor offense.
Not to commit an offense means to subdue and eliminate evil in order to increase goodness, or if it is evil and non-Dharma, it is called not committing an offense.
If a bodhisattva, out of anger, does not stop when others are angry, it is a grave offense.
Not to commit an offense means if one always restrains it but anger still arises, it is called not committing an offense.
If a bodhisattva accepts and keeps a retinue only for the sake of service and clothing and food, it is called committing an offense.
If a bodhisattva gives rise to lazy thoughts, enjoys eating at improper times, and greedily clings to sleep, leaning or lying down, it is a grave offense.

Not to commit an offense means if one is sick, insane, without skillful means, if one is traveling on a road, if one is exhausted, or if one always restrains it, it is called not committing an offense.
If a bodhisattva, with a defiled mind, talks about worldly pleasures, he commits a grave offense.
If he talks about them by mistake, he commits a minor offense.
There is no offense if he answers a question with a few words, or if he talks about something he has heard, or if he talks about the Dharma, this is not an offense.

If a bodhisattva, who wishes to sit in meditation, knows that someone else has the Dharma, but out of anger or arrogance is unable to lower himself to request the Dharma from the other person, he commits a grave offense.
If he does not request it out of laziness, he commits a minor offense.

There is no offense if he is sick or lacks the ability, if he knows that the other person does not follow the Dharma teachings, or if he himself has the ability and has learned much and is able to concentrate his mind, this is not an offense.
If a bodhisattva gives rise to desire realm desires and does not quickly eliminate them by contemplating their antidotes, he commits a grave offense.
There is no offense if he constantly strives to eliminate the desire mind and it still arises, this is not an offense.
The other hindrances are also like this.
If a bodhisattva is attached to the taste of meditation and attached to its merits, they commit a grave offense of contaminated wrongdoing.
If they always wish to abandon attachment but the mind of attachment still arises, this is not an offense.
A bodhisattva who sees like this and speaks like this:
'A bodhisattva should not listen to, accept, recite, or study the Å›rÄvaka canon.
What use is it for a bodhisattva to study this?'
If they speak like this, they commit a grave offense of contaminated wrongdoing.
Why is this?
A bodhisattva should study even the scriptures of non-Buddhists, let alone the Buddha's words!
If it is in order to subdue the Å›rÄvakas and cause them to enter the Great Vehicle, this is not an offense.
If a bodhisattva completely abandons the bodhisattva canon and greedily studies and recites the Å›rÄvaka sÅ«tras, they commit a minor offense of wrongdoing.
If a bodhisattva does not diligently study the Buddha's canon but instead diligently studies non-Buddhist secular texts, they commit a grave offense of contaminated wrongdoing.

Not violating means if one's faculties are extremely sharp and can uphold it upon hearing it once, or if one uses the same words as the Buddha to assist in teaching, using those wonderful words to clarify the Buddha's teachings, and the meaning and purport of the Buddha's sutras and teachings are unshakable, this is called not violating.
Bodhisattvas, if they wish to study the scriptures of non-Buddhists, should study as above.
If they enjoy it and give rise to an attached mind, it is like taking bitter medicine. If they violate this, they commit a grave offense of defilement.

Bodhisattvas, if they hear the profound, secret, and ultimate truth of the bodhisattva canon, and the inconceivable events that are purely the realm of buddhas and bodhisattvas, and give rise to a slanderous mind towards this meaning, saying:
'This meaning is useless, it was not spoken by the Buddha, and it cannot benefit all sentient beings.'
If one slanders in this way, they commit a grave offense of defilement.
Not violating means if one contemplates the definitive meaning, or if one explains skillfully, this is called not violating.
If a bodhisattva hears the profound meaning and does not give rise to faith, in order to cultivate faith with a sincere mind, he should think like this:
'I should not be like this.
I am like one who is blind, without the eye of wisdom.
How can I slander what is spoken by the Buddha's mouth?'
In this way, the bodhisattva reproaches himself for his delusion. This is the Buddha's realm, not something I can reach. If he is able to be like this, this is right practice.
If the mind does not understand but does not give rise to slander, this is called not an offense.
If a bodhisattva, for the sake of food and drink, with an angry and evil mind praises himself and slanders others, he commits a serious offense of contaminated wrongdoing.

If it is in order to subdue non-Buddhists, to subdue arrogance and increase the Buddha's teachings, or if it is in order to make the unbelieving believe and increase the faith of those who already believe, this is called not an offense.

If a bodhisattva, in a place where the Dharma is being taught, in a place where the Vinaya is being explained, or in a place of a great Dharma assembly, with a mind of anger, jealousy, or arrogance does not go to listen, he commits a serious offense of contaminated wrongdoing.
If one is lazy and does not go to listen, one commits a minor offense.

There is no offense if one does not hear about it oneself or if no one invites one, if one is sick, if one has no skill, if one knows that the Dharma being taught does not accord with the principles, if one knows that the teacher has difficulties with oneself, if one knows that the teaching is no different from what one has already heard, if one has attained dhÄraá¹‡Ä« and has heard much, or if one is diligently cultivating wholesome roots. This is called not committing an offense.

Bodhisattvas, when someone asks them to help with matters, such as going together, returning together, assisting with various affairs, managing and protecting property, reconciling disputes, preparing food and drink, and cultivating meritorious deeds,ğŸ”½if they do not do one or two things, they commit a serious offense.
If they are lazy and do not do it, they commit a minor offense.

Not violating means if one is sick, if one does not have the skill, if one has one's own affairs, if the other can manage, if one is not asked to do so, if it is a useless matter, if it is for taming and eliminating evil and increasing goodness, if one is not asked by others, if one is diligently cultivating the roots of goodness in return for others' work, if one is oneself dull and fears losing one's work sequence, if there is a monastic rule to protect the minds of many people, this is called not violating.
If a bodhisattva, seeing sick sentient beings, does not care for them with an evil mind or an angry mind, they commit a grave offense.
If they are lazy and do not care for them, they commit a minor offense.

Not violating means if one has a disease oneself, if there is no skillful means, if one asks others to take care of them, if the sick person has their own relatives, if one knows the sick person can take care of themselves, if the illness is chronic, if the person can still move around, if one wishes to diligently cultivate supreme wholesome roots, if one is extremely dull and fears losing the sequence, if losing the care is like the illness, and if one is poor and suffering, this is called not violating.
Bodhisattvas, seeing sentient beings in front who should have benefits, are unable to give rise to skillful means.
If bodhisattvas, with an evil mind or an angry mind, do not teach them, they commit a grave offense.
If they do not teach out of laziness, they commit a minor offense.

Not violating means if there are no skillful means, if one has others teach, if they have their own good teachers, if it is for taming and subduing evil and increasing goodness, if showing them skillful means only makes them angrier and more rebellious, if they have no respect or love and are obstinate and self-willed, this is called not violating.
Bodhisattvas, when receiving the necessities from sentient beings, should remember their kindness.
If with an evil mind or an angry mind they do not remember or repay kindness, they commit a grave offense.
If they are lazy and do not repay, they commit a minor offense.
If they themselves have no power, no skillful means, or if they wish to tame and extinguish evil and increase goodness, and the benefactor does not accept their repayment, this is not an offense.
Bodhisattvas, seeing people's relatives dying, or losing property and various sufferings,
if with an evil mind or an angry mind they do not go to console them, they commit a grave offense.
If they are as previously explained in the chapter on entrusting bodhisattvas, it is not an offense.
Bodhisattvas, if someone asks for food and drink, and they do not give what is needed, they commit a grave offense.

If they themselves have no possessions, or if they ask for impure things, or if it is for taming and extinguishing evil and increasing goodness, or if it is prohibited by the king, or if it is to protect the monastic rules, this is not an offense.
Bodhisattvas and disciples should teach according to the time.
If the disciples are in need, they should encourage those with deep faith to provide for them.
If one does not teach or provide for them with an evil or angry mind, one commits a grave offense.
If one does not teach or provide for them with a lazy mind, one commits a minor offense.

Not committing an offense means if one is subduing evil and increasing goodness, if one is guarding the limits of the Saá¹…gha, if one is sick, if one does not have the skill, if one asks someone else to teach, if the disciple's merit can attract offerings, or if the disciple is originally a non-Buddhist with no good intentions, this is called not committing an offense.
Bodhisattvas, if with an angry or evil mind they do not protect the intentions of others, they commit a grave offense.
If they do not protect the intentions of others with laziness or negligence, they commit a minor offense.

Not violating means if it is not a matter of the Dharma, if one is sick, if there is a limit of the Saá¹…gha to protect the intentions of many people, if it is a non-Buddhist, if it is to subdue and eliminate evil and increase goodness, this is called not violating.
If a bodhisattva, seeing the virtuous practices of others, is unable to praise them, and with an evil mind or an angry mind conceals the good of others, they commit a grave offense.
If they are lazy and negligent and do not praise the good of others, they commit a minor offense.

Not violating means if they know that the other person does not enjoy praise, if they are sick or lack skillful means, if it is to subdue and eliminate evil and increase goodness, if it is to protect the limit of the Saá¹…gha, if they know that hearing praise will give rise to arrogance, if they have no real virtues, if what seems like good is actually not well-meaning, if it is for non-Buddhists, if the praise has not yet arrived, this is called not violating.
If a bodhisattva, as the head of many people, sees their relatives acting contrary to the Dharma and should be scolded or expelled,
If one does not reprimand and correct with a mind of anger or malice, one commits a grave offense.
If one does not teach or reprimand due to laziness or negligence, one commits a minor offense.

Not committing an offense means if one knows that person is ill-tempered and easily angered, and will not accept reprimand, or if one waits for the right time to teach and reprimand, or if one fears breaking the harmony of the Sangha, or if one knows that person is straightforward, has few inhibitions due to past habits, and likes to repent frequently, this is called not committing an offense.
Bodhisattvas, with spiritual powers and transformations, should manifest according to sentient beings' needs and circumstances, or use skillful means to frighten them to give rise to faith.
If one does not manifest transformations out of fear of the offerings of the faithful, one commits a minor offense.

Not committing an offense means if a person is deeply attached to evil dharmas and wrong views, if they are non-Buddhists, if they slander sages, if they are attached to wrong views, if they are insane or sick, this is called not committing an offense.

Bodhisattvas, with the perfection of the aggregate of precepts, attain immeasurable wonderful fruits. By the power of the causes and conditions of this aggregate of precepts, they perfect the perfection of morality.
Although the recipient has not yet attained supreme perfect enlightenment, they will attain the five merits and virtues in full:
First, they will always be protected and remembered by the Buddhas and Bodhisattvas;
Second, they will always experience pure bliss;
Third, they will have no regrets at the time of death;
Fourth, they will be reborn in the Buddha-lands after leaving the body;
Fifth, they will adorn supreme perfect enlightenment.
The Bodhisattva who upholds the Bodhisattva precepts does not do so for his own sake, but only for the benefit of others and to adorn supreme perfect enlightenment.

These Bodhisattva precepts are all accomplished by the Buddhas and Bodhisattvas of the past, present, and future, as numerous as the sands of the Ganges River, and so are the Buddhas and Bodhisattvas of the ten directions.
The Bodhisattva's vast compassion and universal grace benefit the six realms of beings and the eight difficulties of the three evil paths, and none in the ten directions are not benefited.
The merit is immeasurable, the blessings and wisdom are like space,
Having briefly explained the general precepts, they joyfully pay homage and practice them.
Universally giving rise to the bodhi mind, merit, wisdom, and life are accomplished,
Compassion and kindness are the long-lasting son and daughter, joy and equanimity are born in sequence.
All attain the path of Buddhahood, forever ending without remainder,
The ten directions have the same aspiration, lofty and supreme.

If one wishes to be a bodhisattva upÄsaka who is lax in the five precepts and deportment, if there is no teacher from whom to receive them, at that time the recipient, if there is no teacher, should take the vow in front of a Buddha image.
The deportment of a bodhisattva upÄsaka should be like this: bowing, baring the right shoulder, kneeling on the right knee, with palms joined, one should say:

'I, [name], declare to the Buddhas of the ten directions and the Bodhisattvas dwelling on the grounds, now in the presence of the Buddhas, wish to receive all precepts, learn all Bodhisattva precepts, the five precepts of an upÄsaka, the precepts of gathering all wholesome dharmas, and the Bodhisattva precepts for benefiting sentient beings.

These precepts were already practiced by the Bodhisattvas of the past, will be practiced by the Bodhisattvas of the future, and are now practiced by the Bodhisattvas of the present. I will also practice in the same way.'
The second and third recitations are also like this.
The other matters should be explained in detail as before.
The upÄsaka who is free from desire and fully practices the five precepts, is far removed from the four evils of the body:
First, killing; second, stealing; third, sexual misconduct; fourth, drinking alcohol.
He is far removed from the five evils of speech:
First, false speech; second, harsh speech; third, divisive speech; fourth, meaningless speech; fifth, frivolous speech.
He is far removed from the five wrong livelihoods:
First, selling meat, second, selling alcohol, third, selling poison, fourth, selling living beings, fifth, selling weapons.
Far away from the five things of adornment:
First, incense, second, flowers, third, necklaces, fourth, anointing the body with fragrant oil, fifth, perfuming clothes with incense.
Far away from the five things of indulgence:
First, singing, second, dancing, third, making music, fourth, adorning musical instruments, fifth, not going to watch or listen.
These five precepts are to be followed according to one's ability. If one can fully observe the five for one's whole life, it is best;
If one cannot, one may observe them for as many months, years, days, or nights as one can, or even temporarily for a short time.
